cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to film form (including style and narration), different types of films, and popular approaches to the study of cinema. Topics include: narrative cinema, documentary, avant-garde, genre, authorship, ideology, and representation.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Film Study

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, hybrid course. Lectures and film screenings will be given asynchronously as 1hr and 1.5-3hrs online videos/class, respectively. Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online discussion, with the class split into two 1hr/class sessions (Monday and Wednesday 2-3PM or 3-4PM, Eastern Time Zone) to ask questions and clarifications about lecture and screening content. Students need Power Point, VLC media player (or similar), and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

cmCourseInfo.description: Course on special topics in Cinema Studies. Topics vary each year.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Cinema Studies

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, asynchronous course.
Lectures and tutorials will be given as 2-3hr online videos/week asynchronously. Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online webinar classes 1-2hrs/week (Tuesday and Thursday 2-3pm Eastern Time Zone) to ask questions and clarifications about lecture and tutorial content.
Students need PowerPoint and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra). Students will be asked to watch two films every week as a replacement for the course screening period.

cmCourseInfo.description: Course on selected topics in Cinema Studies. Past topics include: "New Media."
cmCourseInfo.title: Selected Topics in Cinema Studies

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, hybrid course. Lectures will be given as 1-2hr online videos/week asynchronously. Screenings will also be carried out asynchronously. Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online webinar class 1-2hrs/week (Monday and Wednesday 3-4pm Eastern Time Zone) to ask questions and clarifications about lecture content. Students need Power Point and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra). Students should also have Internet access to download lecture content, and stream or rent films. If students participate in the synchronous online webinar, they must have access to a webcam and microphone.

courses.name: Special Topics in Cinema as Social and Cultural Practice

sections.name: LEC5101
sections.subTitle: The Anarchy of the Senses: The Films of Nagisa Oshima and Rainer Werner Fassbinder

cmCourseInfo.description: Courses in special topics designed for Specialists and Majors in Cinema Studies. Past topics include: "History of Cinematography," and "Everyday Life in the Digital Age."
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Cinema as Social and Cultural Practice

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, synchronous course. Lectures and discussions will take place via video conference using Blackboard Collaborate through Quercus on Monday and Wednesday 5-7pm Eastern Time Zone. Asynchronous learning for students facing geographical or technical constraints (i.e., students currently residing in a different time zone, or students with limited access to a computer or the internet) can be arranged upon approval by the instructor, and will entail making recorded lectures available together with alternative methods for discussion/participation. Students will need to be able to access Quercus and use Blackboard Collaborate.

courses.name: Special Topics in Theory and Criticism

cmCourseInfo.description: Courses in special topics designed for Specialists and Majors in Cinema Studies. Past topics include: "Cinema and Intermediality."
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Theory and Criticism

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is a hybrid, online course. Lectures will be given as 2-3hr online videos/week asynchronously. Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online webinar class 1-2hrs/week (Tuesday and Thursday 1-2pm Eastern Time Zone) to have discussion, ask questions and clarifications about lecture content. Students need Power Point and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

courses.name: Special Topics in History and Nation

sections.name: LEC0101
sections.subTitle: Revisiting French New Wave: Culture & Technology

cmCourseInfo.description: Courses in special topics designed for Specialists and Majors in Cinema Studies.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in History and Nation

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, hybrid course. Lectures will be given as 2-3hr online videos/week asynchronously. Online webinar class will be given as 1-2hrs/week (Monday and Wednesday 3-4pm Eastern Time Zone). During the webinars, students will be given the opportunity to discuss the screening and ask questions and clarifications about lecture content. Students need Power Point and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra) with video feed.

cmCourseInfo.description: See course description for CIN492H1 listed below. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Independent Studies in Cinema
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: At least ten full-course equivalents, including CIN105Y1, CIN201Y1, CIN301Y1/ permission of instructor

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Please note: Students must complete CIN105Y1, CIN201Y1, and CIN301Y1 before taking any fourth year Cinema Studies courses. For "E" indicator Cinema Studies Courses: Contact the Undergraduate Assistant, 416-978-8571, cinema.studies@utoronto.ca

cmCourseInfo.description: Independent research projects devised by students and supervised by Cinema Studies faculty. Open to advanced Specialist and Major students in the Program. Submit applications to the Undergraduate Program Office: Fall 2016 courses, June 1/ Winter 2017 courses, November 1/ Summer 2017 courses, April 1. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
